signals.raw_text:
The Kobeissi Letter
US productivity is surging:

US labor productivity soared by an annualized +4.9% in Q3 2025, the strongest pace in 2 years.

This follows an upwardly revised +4.1% increase in Q2, marking the 2nd consecutive quarter with productivity gains above 4.0%.

Unit labor costs, which signal how much a company pays workers to produce one unit of output, fell -1.9% in Q3, following a decline in Q2, the first back-to-back declines since 2019.

This comes as many businesses are using new technology and equipment to improve worker efficiency.

The combination of rising productivity and falling labor costs should ease inflationary pressure from wages while supporting economic growth.

However, this also signals that companies can effectively grow without the need to add new workers.

Has the AI productivity boom arrived?
tweet

Unit labor costs fell -1.9% in Q3, marking the first back-to-back declines since 2019. This productivity boom is driven by businesses adopting new technology and equipment to improve worker efficiency. Rising productivity and falling labor costs should ease inflationary pressure from wages, supporting economic growth. However, this also suggests companies can grow without hiring more workers, potentially impacting employment figures. The confluence of these factors suggests a significant shift in the economic landscape. This trend warrants close monitoring as it could reshape monetary policy and corporate investment strategies. The AI productivity boom may be underway, presenting both opportunities and challenges for investors. Consider long positions in companies enabling productivity gains and short positions in sectors vulnerable to automation.

RT @buckeyevn: @cursor_ai 3M-line ‚Äúrebuild a browser‚Äù attempt is the most interesting agent demo I‚Äôve seen so far in 2026, not for the code volume but because it reveals the benchmark we actually need.

To solve long-horizon software engineering, we need a new SWE-bench. DARPA-style: build something big, then grade only the artifact at the end.

Browsers already have the scoreboard: BrowserBench (Speedometer, JetStream, MotionMark) for performance, and Web Platform Tests for compatibility.

The code isn‚Äôt the point. The shipped system is. We‚Äôre entering an era where code becomes a means, not the product.

Faster inference (e.g. OpenAI + Cerebras) compresses the loop, which is exactly what long-horizon tasks need.

If this goes from ‚Äúattempted‚Äù to ‚Äúsolved‚Äù in 6‚Äì12 months, what does software engineering become?

We built a browser with GPT-5.2 in Cursor. It ran uninterrupted for one week.

It's 3M+ lines of code across thousands of files. The rendering engine is from-scratch in Rust with HTML parsing, CSS cascade, layout, text shaping, paint, and a custom JS VM.

It *kind of* works! It still has issues and is of course very far from Webkit/Chromium parity, but we were astonished that simple websites render quickly and largely correctly. - Michael Truell

This $11 gap is nearly double the previous record from 2011, and it signals that the global silver market is fracturing.

The core problem is structural scarcity colliding with surging demand. 

The market has been running a deficit for five consecutive years, and about 75 percent of silver is a byproduct of copper mining, miners can't just produce more when prices spike. 

Meanwhile, demand is explosive. 

Solar panels consume roughly 197 million ounces annually because silver is the only metal that works for their electrical layers, and each EV uses double the silver of a traditional car. 

Data centers for AI are adding yet another consumption layer. 

Industrial demand hit a record 680 million ounces last year, and supply can't keep pace.‚Äã‚Äã

What's changed everything is that China implemented harsh export controls on silver, restricting it to only 44 state approved firms and effectively ringfencing supply for its own industries solar, EVs, electronics. 

China is the world's second largest silver producer and controls roughly 70 percent of the global refined market. 

By tightening exports, it's signaling that silver, like rare earths before it, is now a strategic commodity, not just a traded one. 

Western traders have been buying silver at spot and shipping it to China to capture the premium, draining Western inventories. 

Lease rates have spiked above 8 percent and visible stockpiles are collapsing.‚Äã

Expecting this shortage to continue throughout 2026 and into 2027.

analysis.summary: Silver prices are poised for continued appreciation due to a confluence of factors creating a perfect storm. A structural supply deficit, exacerbated by five consecutive years of market imbalance, is colliding with surging industrial demand, particularly from solar panels, EVs, and AI data centers. China's strategic shift, implementing stringent export controls on silver and prioritizing domestic industries, is further tightening global supply. The Shanghai premium has exploded to $11 per ounce, nearly double the 2011 record, signaling a fracturing global market. Western inventories are being depleted as traders arbitrage the premium, leading to spiking lease rates above 8 percent. China's control of 70% of the refined silver market amplifies the impact of its export restrictions. This supply squeeze is expected to persist throughout 2026 and into 2027, driving prices higher. Silver's unique properties in solar panel production and increasing usage in EVs solidify its demand. The market is underestimating the impact of China's policy and the inelasticity of silver supply as a copper mining byproduct.

Job openings for US economists are falling:

Job openings for economists dropped -21% YoY in December 2025, to ~1,773, the lowest since at least 2019.

This marks the 3rd consecutive annual decline.

The weakness was broad-based across sectors, with full-time academic positions dropping -33% YoY.

At the same time, Federal government job listings dropped -71% YoY, to just 24.

The number of job openings in business and finance has also weakened for a third year.

As a result, total available vacancies for economists are -43% below the 2019 pre-pandemic levels.

The economics job market is experiencing one of its worst downturns in history.
tweet

signals.raw_text:
Marginal REVOLUTION
Is there a British productivity comeback?
Let us hope:

Britain is seeing early signs of a long-awaited turnaround of its productivity woes, according to an alternative measure that suggests output per hour worked has risen at a pace not seen since before the financial crisis.

The Resolution Foundation¬†said a ‚Äúblistering‚Äù productivity surge has been masked by problems with official statistics and pointed to encouraging indications of a clearout of ‚Äúzombie‚Äù firms that contribute little to the economy.

Productivity growth, when measured using the Office for National Statistics‚Äô troubled Labour Force Survey, was just 1.1% in the year through the third quarter of 2025. But the figures look far better when based on employee payrolls data that are more trusted by economists, the think tank said.

‚ÄúProductivity was essentially flat between the pre-pandemic peak of Q4 2019 and post-pandemic trough of Q1 2024, but it has grown by a blistering 3.4% in the six quarters after that, a rate not seen since before the financial crisis,‚Äù the Resolution Foundation said in a report published Monday. Those gains are more than the previous seven years combined, it added.

Here is more from Bloomberg.¬† I will update you on this as I learn more.

The post Is there a British productivity comeback? appeared first on Marginal REVOLUTION.

analysis.summary: The Resolution Foundation suggests a British productivity surge, masked by issues with official statistics. Using payroll data, productivity grew 3.4% in the six quarters after Q1 2024, a rate unseen since before the financial crisis. This contrasts with the official Labour Force Survey's 1.1% growth through Q3 2025. The Foundation highlights a potential clearout of "zombie" firms as a contributing factor. This productivity surge exceeds the gains of the previous seven years combined. Bloomberg also reported on this potential turnaround. If sustained, this productivity growth could significantly boost the UK's economic outlook. Investors should monitor payroll data for confirmation of this trend. A productivity resurgence could lead to increased corporate profitability and higher wages. This warrants further investigation into the underlying drivers and sustainability of the reported gains.
analysis.fact_check: Claim: Productivity growth was 1.1% in the year through Q3 2025 using the Labour Force Survey. Verdict: True, according to the Resolution Foundation report referencing ONS data. Claim: Productivity grew by 3.4% in the six quarters after Q1 2024 using payroll data. Verdict: True, according to the Resolution Foundation report. Claim: The 3.4% growth rate is not seen since before the financial crisis. Verdict: Likely True, based on the Resolution Foundation's statement. Claim: Productivity was essentially flat between Q4 2019 and Q1 2024. Verdict: True, according to the Resolution Foundation report.
analysis.analysis: The argument hinges on the discrepancy between two different measures of productivity. The author highlights the Resolution Foundation's preference for payroll data over the Labour Force Survey, suggesting the latter is underestimating productivity growth. The 'variant perception' is that the UK economy is experiencing a stronger productivity rebound than official statistics indicate. A potential bias is the reliance on a single think tank's report. The analysis lacks discussion of potential risks or alternative explanations for the data discrepancy. The credibility is moderate, pending further corroboration from other sources and analysis of the underlying data.
